Word.Meaning: feel pain in the mouth from tasting something very sour

irriyērum-sakšar-hak-an
idea-RECIP.BEN-1P.INCL.ABS-INTRANS
Lit. "This idea, we share it with each other"

Word.SecondaryMeanings: Lit: to talk as a group for everyone's benefit

Word.Etymology: Derivation into Osprey Speaker “neyūn” (osprey) is metaphor – the raptor is admired for its accuracy

Word.Meaning: avoid, evade (an attack or bodily harm)
badly formed (said of things, not sentient animates)
Word.GrammaticalNotes: Occurs in verb serialization

Word.Meaning: beautiful (said of animals, particularly wild undomesticated animals)
behave like, behave as if, simulate
bend one's face, i.e. pay attention to

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Used when there is no other color-adjective

Word.Meaning: bob up and down in water
brace oneself firmly against an opposing force
clasp, curl one's fingers around something
click (“tap”) the “Like” button on Facebook obsessively all over the place without any self-control
close a door or other opening
create in verbal a verbal trap

Word.AdditionalNotes: “Kaymawākan” is also the name of a deer-ghost in Wolf Speaker myths

Word.Meaning: cut with surgical precision around a wound extract an arrow with a barbed head

Word.GrammaticalNotes: takes Dative argument

Word.Meaning: deliberately descend the lower depths (i.e. gohell)
die in the comfort of one's friends and loved ones

Word.Dialect: Idiom for Impersonal clause constructions: “Suwakammā” + Verb serialization

Word.Meaning: do something in a strange manner
draw out a weapon (eg unsheathe a knife or sword, pull out a gun, etc)
draw the bowstring backward with the arrow ready
dwell (lit. set oneself down in an orderly fashion)

Word.SecondaryMeanings: To be early = “to stand in front of the day”
Word.AdditionalNotes: notice expected -dn- > -nd- metathesis does not occur

Word.Meaning: enjoy the taste of one's food

Word.GrammaticalNotes: takes Dative arg

Word.Meaning: exchange a bad thing for a good thing
exercise responsible stewardship over the earth
exert a lot of effort recall something, and come close remembering it, but the memory still eludes you
Word.GrammaticalNotes: Occurs with the (with Distr). The implicit Agent is “iksēt” (wind), so this really means “the wind blows away something”

Word.Meaning: extremist in political and/or religious ideology
extremist in viewpoint (not necessarily referring to religious or political extremism); to be a lunatic; to be a conspiracy theorist; hold outrageous views
factual, be a fact; be true, ie an observable truth, fact, empirical observation

Word.Etymology: C.f Nankôre “pash” (to set one's foot against a firm object)

Word.Meaning: fall off an edge or ledge
fall on one day (i.e. once upon a time)

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Irregular verb: nihī + C (not expected “nihiyyi” + C)

Word.Meaning: flow, pour down vertically (e.g. waterfall, pouring tea from a pot through the spout, etc)
forget say a prayer a fallen animal's spirit for slaying it in the hunt
fruit, bear fruit/produce for the harvest
gawk; stop and stare (often with Intensive)
gently poach fish in simmering broth very briefly such that the surface is cooked but the flesh underneath is very rare
go north; go to the North Coast
go north; go to Upper Minhay

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Notice NI of “tak” (way/manner)

Word.Meaning: have an advantage, be in an advantageous situation
hold a public ritual; have a festival
hold in the hand; to have
hold in the hand; to have
hunt (actively running after prey);chase after a fugitive
hunt/chase with perfect silence and stealth by hiding behind various objects like trees and boulders

Word.Etymology: Note use of Durative to derive from -dāwap- “to drip”

Word.SecondaryMeanings: utterly mysterious, unknowable; densely tangled brush or woodland

Word.Meaning: join together (e.g. as friends, lovers, or spouses
jump/leap over an obstacle; jump and maneuver in “Parkour” style, combined with rock climbing and boulder scrambling
keep hold of, maintain control over
keep things slowly over an extended period of time due one's own laziness
kneel on both knees (e.g. a cushion)
Word.SecondaryMeanings: Same word in Horse Speaker dialect means “to sit down”

Word.GrammaticalNotes: irregular sound change when it applies NI: ikna

Word.Meaning: know a general truism (not necessarily a fact, cf nusill); know by taking confidence in and taking their word
know about a person or a people (cf Spanish “Conocer”
know the lay of the land, be familiar with a place’s layout
Word.Etymology: Osprey Speaker settlement, easternmost point in Minhay
Irriyaskum: Salmon Speaker military settlement established during the Ainu-Salmon Speaker Wars
Iyyakpe: another Salmon Speaker military settlement on the northern coast of Minhay, established during the Ainu-Salmon Speaker Wars

Word.Meaning: lead an area (e.g. a paths leads the fields)
lead, serve as leader; give instructions for a common goal
Word.Etymology: Peyye: southernmost Osprey Speaker settlement bordering Dog Speaker and Gull Speaker territories
Kask: a large settlement in the southern coast of Minhay

Word.Meaning: lift close in order see and inspect more closely

Word.SecondaryMeanings: Lit: you shall take the hearing, i.e. listen carefully!
Word.GrammaticalNotes: alienable possession

Word.Meaning: long timewise; for a long time elapse
look down from an elevated vantage point

Word.Etymology: causative form of “nusill-”to know a fact

Word.Meaning: make something pliable by beating with a stick
meet at an appointed place, rendezvous
mixed breed (as in mixed tribal parentage)
mount one’s horse; get ina vehicle
NOT want do (trans., does NOT have -u marker)

Word.Etymology: (from šp-inta-nusill-šattar “to intensely cause oneself to know (a) fact(s)”

Word.AdditionalNotes: Do not confuse this with iknatūman “to go home”

Word.Meaning: order, give an order (trans. only, like “sillu”)
outflank in pursuit of something during a hunt (or chasing a fugitive)
pick up something that has fallen down
pinkish-orange, vaguely like color of grapefruit or the inner lobes of Chicken in the Woods

Word.AdditionalNotes: don't confuse this with the noun “kayhat” (box)

Word.Meaning: positioned at a low vantage point
positioned at a low vantage point
possessed by an evil spirit; insane

Word.AdditionalNotes: (note: used by women; it is considered taboo and serious social offense if said by a man)

Word.Meaning: pull an arrow out of flesh

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Do not confuse this with the Necessitative

Word.Meaning: put ina container; put away; keep
put, set, place in an orderly fashion
raise a building, build; invest in infrastructure
raise a weapon strike at someone
raise one's hands in the air calm people
reach for in order pick up
reach out with hands open (usually with Distributive)

Word.AlternateForms: -ayukk- (when followed by affix or IN starting with /p/
Word.GrammaticalNotes: This is considered an irregular verb given that the the root does not follow the phonotactic rules; /p/ + /k/ usually results in /pk/

Word.Meaning: remember something that makes you remember something else that you previously had forgotten
render verdict; pass judgment on someone
rest or lay one’s head, chin, or face on something in a leisurely manner
return the gravesite, place of cremation, or site of death (e.g. a murder) on the anniversary in order mourn and give remembrance

Word.AdditionalNotes: lit: to look back and forth along the scratches (writing

Word.Meaning: run silently for the purpose of attack
say one or two words, make an utterance
say one or two words, make an utterance
scale up a rocky cliff in order harvest sea bird eggs

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Occurs in verb serializationto denote Equalis

Word.Meaning: seek sympathy for one’s own ego
separate, be separate; to be one-of-a-kind
Word.SecondaryMeanings: to be standoffish, to shun (with RFLX); to segregate, impose segregation, to quarantine (with CAUS + INCHO)

Word.Meaning: shake a weapon as a threat

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Note use of Semelfective

Word.Meaning: shoot an arrow on horseback while leaning sideways, therefore shooting the arrow from a horizontal position

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Note Intensive form combined with Dative-Applicative
Note use of Causative

Word.AdditionalNotes: Easter Egg: from Robbie Alan Long

Word.Meaning: sit down by the fire/at the hearth
smell, give an odor, be fragrant

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Note Intensive form

Word.Meaning: spend time w/ s.o/s.t; be married for X years
stand dangerously at the edge of something and risk falling over
stand in front of; be early
stand on firm ground; be certain, sure
stand on something to look over an obstruction
stand over someone; be master of, superior to
step across a boundary, threshold, or a period of time
step over a puddle or a muddy area
step over an object (e.g. step over a puddle)
substitute something in the place of another
take a family member as hostage; commit cultural appropriation
take advantage of an opportunity, exploit

Word.Etymology: Root: yuhar Lit: to cause oneself to be a circle around s.t.
Word.GrammaticalNotes: Note combination of Causative and Reflexive affixes

Word.Meaning: thank an animal spirit for surrendering its life so that the hunter and his family may live
think about a topic, ponder, plan a solution for something

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Note use of Causative and Intensive affixes

Word.Meaning: thunder, boom, make an explosive sound
to lose a mother in childbirth
to lose both one’s wife and child in childbirth
trap someone verbally in an argument
trap with a rope or snare
true (non-empirical,i.e. subjective truth, “heart”-truth), “to give an opinion that is true because it is self-evident” not based on evidence but on philosophy; to tell the truth
tumble from the air towards the earth (vs. tumbling ON the GROUND)

Word.GrammaticalNotes: Note use of Durative derivational affix “-ħtaš-”

Word.Meaning: use an instrument or other tool
use the discourse particle “anda” when the polite form “šendek” was not tried prior for the prerequisite 5 times; be rude, without manners; be pushy and aggressive
use the discourse particle “šenek” when the more forceful form “anda” should be used; be meek and docile; be a pushover
visit relatives after a long extended absence
wake up, get up,arise from sleep
walk between two or more objects
walk downwards from upper elevations (i.e. a mountain or hillside, which is slightly different from “descend”)
walk specifically on a path or road
want someone else to do/perform an action (trans., does NOT have -u marker)
warn of impending danger, sound the alarm

Word.Etymology:
Complex derivation: kaħt-sar-tahipna << INV.CTRL + root + NI (-tahipn-)
Root: -sar-

Word.Meaning: work, perform work; be busy, preoccupied with a task
wound s.o. in the back with an arrow; considered a term of dishonor when the wounded target is a Horse Speaker; also considered an insult a Horse Speaker
wrap around something like a vine, entwine
you did not even try get them reconsider the evidence
